entry.title: Combined summary - [BUG]: spammers get Bitcoin blockspace at discounted price. Let's fix it
entry.summary:
The blog post critically examines the complexities surrounding blockchain transaction costs and the fairness of block space pricing. It highlights the issue that simple Bitcoin transactions may face price discrimination, thus questioning their efficiency within the network's fee structure. The discussion reveals a disparity between the cost of witness data and state transition data to node-runners, suggesting that the current witness discount does not accurately reflect their true resource costs. Moreover, it emphasizes that while processing state-transition data is crucial for syncing the blockchain, witness data's importance diminishes over time due to PoW compressing historical data.
In addressing block space pricing, the post proposes a standardized cost across different transaction types to prevent economic transactions from being disadvantaged. This proposal is backed by an analysis comparing SegWit and non-SegWit transactions, demonstrating the financial impact on Bitcoin users. The challenge of BRC-20 protocols and spam cryptocurrencies is also discussed, showing how they optimize blockchain space usage and result in high fees during peak demand, thereby disadvantaging standard Bitcoin users.
The email concludes with a critique of unmet expectations regarding blockchain advancements, such as increased capacity and reduced fees through witness data discounts. It notes the ongoing competition between legitimate transactions and spam and questions the proposed equation meant to discourage excessive use of witness space without affecting regular users. The effectiveness of this solution is doubted, especially with the rise of more efficient asset protocols.
The blog advocates for a fairer approach to transaction cost allocation in the Bitcoin network, taking into account both technical considerations and user implications. To illustrate the inconsistencies in transaction fees, two specific Bitcoin transactions are contrasted, where a simpler transaction could incur a higher fee than a more complex one, as detailed on mempool.space ([Transaction 1](https://mempool.space/tx/aabbcce67f2aa71932f789cac5468d39e3d2224d8bebb7ca2c3bf8c41d567cdd), [Transaction 2](https://mempool.space/tx/1c35521798dde4d1621e9aa5a3bacac03100fca40b6fb99be546ec50c1bcbd4a)). This counterintuitive pricing leads to concerns about misallocation of block space and potential centralization risks.
A uniform pricing strategy is suggested as a solution to ensure fair pricing for all transactions. By equally valuing each byte regardless of its position in a transaction, biases favoring complex transactions would be eliminated. The implementation of this system could create standardized transaction costs, adjust incentives, and rectify current vulnerabilities in the blockchain ecosystem. The author calls for consensus on this approach to correct the skewed incentives and flaws in the existing system.
